text:
At the heart of any case, any
great case, is a great story.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

To invite people into a
case is to invite people

into a set of
generalizable principles

that at the beginning of a
session they may not realize
is the case.

But as they dig into a case,
and they see the complexity,

and how it plays out, a
fantastic case discussion

ends where you say, wait a
minute, that might just be me.

Cases are centered around
the same principles of,

why is this happening
the way it is?

And over the next hour and a
half, can we try to figure out,

what do we learn that
can be applied elsewhere?

When we write articles,
we have reviewers.

When we write books,
we have critics.

But when we write cases,
we have co-creators.

Every single individual
in the classroom
becomes our collaborator.

And the outcome is not
pre-written, but rather

an evolution of
anything any one of us
might have thought before.

Relationships, especially
in the classroom,
are built on trust and respect.

But they're cemented together
through a shared experience.

Doing two or three cases a
week with the same people

and a faculty member creates
that shared experiences.

And those cases then
become touchstones.

And years later when people
recall those milestone cases

that cause one to re-examine
their point of arrival,

or their assumptions, that
pivotal moment where they
changed--

they were transformed from
a classmate's insight--
I think that is profound.

So much of my research focuses
on topics related to diversity.

And because our
classrooms have people

from such a wide range
of different experiences

and walks of life, whenever
we have a case discussion,

it allows us to surface many
different points of view.

And ultimately to put people
into different positions

that they've never
thought about before.

And this, to me, is one
of the most amazing ways

to communicate concepts
about diversity.
